qas.question: What made identifying House leadership difficult?
How many candidates was typical in early fields for speaker?
From 1861 to 1875 how many times was Dmocratic minority speaker not nominated?
What atmosphere was most prevalent in congress from 1834 through 1859?

plausible_answers.text: identifying lawmakers who might have informally functioned as a minority leader

qas.question: What did the Democratic minority make more difficult in 1834?
What did Democrats assume the role of in 1855?
What were Democrats not automatically looked to for in 1834?
How many candidates were there from 1861-1875 for speaker?

context: <a0_0><b3_0>Internal party disunity<b3_0/><a0_0/> compounded the difficulty of <b4_0>identifying lawmakers who might have informally functioned as a minority leader<b4_0/>. For instance, "seven of the fourteen speakership elections from 1834 through 1859 had <a1_0><b7_0>at least twenty<b7_0/> different candidates<a1_0/> in the field. Thirty-six competed in 1839, ninety-seven in 1849, ninety-one in 1859, and 138 in 1855." With so many candidates competing for the speakership, it is not at all clear that one of the defeated lawmakers then assumed the mantle of <b5_0>"minority leader."<b5_0/> The Democratic minority from 1861 to 1875 was so completely disorganized that they did not "nominate a candidate for Speaker in <a2_0>two of these seven Congresses<a2_0/> and nominated no man more than once in the other five. The defeated candidates were not automatically looked to for <b6_0>leadership<b6_0/>."
